resource.chars:
36  The addition of new zones usually takes place with the same
regularity in the complex as in the simple types of structure; but
departures from this regularity, occasioned by a want of completeness
of particular zones (such as are seen in Plate V, Fig 5,) are more
frequent; and this perhaps to be accounted-for by the larger
size of the disk, which will tend to produce less intimate
dependence of each part of the animal body upon every other, and
will thus favour the partial action of any cause (e.g. an excess
of nutri<s>m</s>ent materials) which promotes a more rapid growth on
one side than the other. And this view is most remarkably
borne-out by the fact, which I shall more fully illustrate in a
subsequent memoir, that in another example of this group [<u>Note</u>
[I refer to a genus hitherto undescribed, which I shall designate
<u>Cycloclypeus</u>.] which, though normally growing upon the cyclical
type, possess a greater degree of segmental independence, such
irregularities occur far more frequently; so that in fact, it is rare to meet
with a disk whose increase has taken-place with uniformity throughout.

37. <u>Reparation of Injuries</u>. Looking at the vegetative repetition
of parts which pre-eminently characterises the body of the Orbitolite; -
